text: Family International is a New Age religion and a cult.Huxley J 1992. Sunday Times: Sex-cult children held – Children of God. The Sunday Times (Sydney) 17 May 1992. It was formerly called The Children of God, The Family of Love and The Family. It was started in the 1960s in California by David Brandt Berg (1919–1994). == History == The Family International (TFI) has had several different names: * The Children of God (1968–1977) * The Family of Love (1978–1981) * The Family (1982–1994) * The Family International (2004 onwards) The Chinese government identified TFI as a cult in the 1990s.Cao Siqi. Hubei police detain three cult members. Global Times. 2014-11-18.欧阳智慧 陈世华. 邪教“天父的儿女”3名骨干落网 该教倡“群居滥交”, Phoenix Television, 2014-11-17. ==Overview== Broadly, TFI is a Christian evangelical movement. However, their beliefs are selective. Their "spiritual revolution" is against the outside world, which the members called "the System". After the death of the founder, his widow Karen Zerby became the leader of TFI, taking the title of 'Queen' and 'prophetess.' She married Steve Kelly, an assistant of David Berg whom Berg had chosen as her 'consort' before his death. Steve Kelly took the title of 'King Peter' and became the public face of TFI, speaking in a more public capacity than either David Berg or Karen Zerby. == 'Flirty Fishing' == In 1974, the group began a method of evangelism called Flirty Fishing. This meant using sex to "show God's love" and win converts.xFamily.org Publications Database — contains the entire text of "Mo Letters" The method was apparently extremely successful. According to TFI, as a result of Flirty Fishing, "over 100,000 received God's gift of salvation through Jesus, and some chose to live the life of a disciple and missionary".The origins of a movement: from "The Children of God" to "The Family International", [] === Sexual abuse === The group encouraged children to have sex with adults and each other. In the United Kingdom, the High Court of Justice's Family Division found there to be "widespread sexual abuse of young children and teenagers by adult members of The Family". According to data provided by TFI to researcher Bill Bainbridge, from 1974 until 1987, members had sexual contact with 223,989 people while practicing Flirty Fishing.Bainbridge, William Sims 1996. The sociology of religious movements. Routledge, p223. Flirty Fishing also resulted in the births of many children, including Karen Zerby's son, Davidito (aka Ricky Rodriguez). He committed suicide after murdering a female member of the cult who had sexually abused him as a toddler. Children born as result of Flirty Fishing were referred to as "Jesus Babies". By the end of 1981, more than 300 "Jesus Babies" had been born. === TFI custody case === In his judgment of a child custody court case in England in 1994, after extensive research of COG publications and the testimony of numerous witnesses, Lord Justice Sir Alan Ward said this about Flirty Fishing: === Later corrections === Flirty Fishing was officially abandoned in 1987. After some complaints from people who had been abused as children by adults, the organization made a rule that sexual interactions should not occur between an adult and a minor. The rule was encouraged and promoted, but not enforced. In March 1989, TFI sent an urgent memorandum to all of its members "reminding them that any such activities [adult-child sexual contact] are strictly forbidden within our group".Child Abuse?! (March 1989) (Hosted by xfamily.org) According to In January 2005, Claire Borowik, spokesperson for TFI > [Because] our current zero-tolerance policy regarding sexual interaction > between adults and underage minors was not clearly stated in our literature > published before 1986, we came to the realization that during a transitional > stage of our movement, from 1978 until 1986, there were cases when some > minors were subject to sexually inappropriate advances... This was corrected > officially in 1986, when any contact between an adult and minor (any person > under 21 years of age) was declared an excommunicable offense". == Today == According to a 2025 article, at the beginning of the 21st century, there were around 10,000 TFI members in more than 90 countries. The same article calls TFI "the most successful communal group to emerge from the 1960s counterculture era." == Further reading == *Chancellor, James 2000.
